pageContext.desc: One of the first female surgeons in the United States.
transcription:
Somerset, Mich. Dec. 30, 1899.
Dear Aunts; I thank you very much for the little book which you so kindly sent me. I went to Hudson for Christmas and had a very good time. I wish you a Happy New Year and hope you had a Merry Christmas. Mamma will send a note.
With love,
Clarence C. Butler.

Hague, N.Y. May 7, 1883
Dear Aunties:
I have been 
here two days, and will write 
you my impressions thus far.  
Spoke twice on Sunday, both 
times without notes, and got along 
very well.  Took the sermon I 
read to you for the first one, 
and the 23rd Psalm for the 
second.  Had a large audience in 
the morning, as they wanted to 
hear the "new minister." In the 
evening there was the usual 
audience of about 60.  There was 
no Sunday School, but one will 
probably be started soon.  The 
prayer meeting comes Thursday 
evening.

I board at present 11/2 miles 
from the church, and 3 miles from 
the lake.  Have plenty of good 
farmer's here, with nice sweet 
butter, milk & cream, excellent 
water and fresh mountain air.  
The scenery around here is very 
fine.  I walked down to the lake 
and back this forenoon, and 
this afternoon went up to the top of 
a mountain near, from which a 
good view is had all around, of 
Lake George, Champlain, Green 
Mts &c.  Got a letter from Father 
enclosing one from Elaine tonight.  
Think they are laying out enough 
work for me, as they want me 
to go out and preach in a school-
house some night this week, and 
also want me to take charge of 
the S.S.  Think now I shall 
speak in the school house Friday night.

Tues. morn
I am going to make some calls 
among the people today.  There is 
a Wesleyan Methodist church near the 
lake, 1 1/2 miles from the Baptist.  
There minister is coming Thursday, 
a new man, just appointed by the 
conference.  He is said to be a 
fair preacher.  There were two 
minsters of that denomination sat 
with me in the pulpit, and 
assisted in the exercises in the 
morning, and one in the evening.  
We had a shower last night 
but the sun shines out fine this 
morning.  It is colder here than 
in N.Y. and seems more like 
Remsen.  Write me about your 
plans, and whether you will go 
to Hillsdale.  Hope you are well.
Yours with love.
J.H.Butler

MORIAH, N. Y.
FEB 13 1886
Mary H. Everett, M.D.
REMSEN,
N.Y.

Moriah, N.Y. Feb. 11, 1886
Dear Aunt Mary;-
It has been so long since 
we have heard from you, that I thought I must 
write.  How are you prospering this cold winter, 
and what do you find to busy yourself about?
We have now been here nearly nine months, 
and have no reason to complain of our treatment
so far.  I have exchanged six times with different 
ministers.  At Crown Point I found a lady, 
a member of Mr. Rossiter's church, who was
stopping there for the summer.  She was the d
daughter of Mr. McDougal, I think.  Yesterday
I had a call from another of your old friends,
Rev. Mr. Jones of Saratoga.  He knew Grandpa
Everett very well, and has preached in his p
pulpit.  He is a very successful pastor.
Last Sunday I spent at Hague, where I
supplied the first year I was in the seminary.
They were glad to see me, and I had a full
house Sunday.  Returned home Monday night. 
I wish you could come and make us a visit.
We should be very glad to see you.  At Christmas 
time we had a tree in the church, and on
it were about $20. worth of presents for the 
pastor and his wife.  We have put $56. worth 
of new books into the S.S. library since we
came here.  Next week Wednesday is to be our
donation.  They usually raise from $50. to
$75. then.  I have quite a bad cough now, 
but got some "Phos." from the doctor here,
and find it helps it.  We have had it very
cold, ther. 23 below zero, but it is now
quite warm, and our sleighing is spoiled.
How do you like the work on my type-writer?

It is the Hall, and I got it for about half-
price.  Think it will be a help to me in my
work.  I wrote part of my sermon on it this 
week.  How are Aunt Jennie and Aunt Anna
this winter?  Suppose John Eddie is in college
as usual.  Our church has been rather cold 
some of the time, as the heating arrangements
are hardly sufficient.  We are holding prayer
meetings now around at the houses.  S.S. and
Sunday congregations keep up pretty well.
The people have sent in pork, sausage,
chickens, &c, so as to supply us pretty well 
with meat during the winter.  They also have
painted the parsonage.  We have some new 
singing books which we use in S.S. and prayer-
meeting.  I have made me a sled with which to draw
in wood from the barn to the house.
I raised plenty of apples, squashes, &c in
the garden last summer.  The apples are
Northern Spies and Spitzenburgs.
We shall hope to hear from you soon.
With love to all,
J.H. Butler

this morning. The rash has not come
out yet on Carroll.  Carroll and 
Robbie cough pretty hard.  Bobby
is pretty well they is not any
signs of the measels to him I am 
pretty glad I am so I can get up
Clara Cornish was over yesterday
and brought her adv. cards and
her scrap book she has got a scrap
book four times as big as ours
but she has not got them pasted
in yet but she has got some
nice ones do you see many 
nice adv. cards now.
Write soon. Love to all from 
all your nephew.
Charlie Everett
P.S.
Carroll sends a card with his name 
on I have not got any yet.

Olpe, Ks. August 19/90.
Dear Aunt Mary and Jennie and all, 
It is just one 
year ago to day that 
Eddie and my self returned 
from Osawatomie and as 
there is a letter on the desk 
addressed to you I 
guess I will drop in a few 
lines.  I have been at home 
all summer, only working in the hay press occasional-
ly.  I expect to go out in 
the country to Mr Ray's about 
next week to help them in 
haying etc.  Carroll and 
I went to the farm last

Thursday and stayed one 
day and had a good time. 
The teachers for the 
primary and higher depart-
ments in our school have 
been secured.  They are two 
sisters whose names are the Misses 
Rudison.  We had a fine 
rain the first of the week 
which I suppose reached you.
Are the crops in Miami 
lev. badly effected by the  
drouth.  I heard they were 
good around Ottawa.  Well, 
I will have to bid you adieu 
from your nephew
Chas Everett

Olpe, Kas.
Jan. 27, 1892.
My Dear Aunts, -
We have heard 
nothing from either of you since 
the letter of of Aunt Mary's from 
Chicago. Has she returned yet? 
Have you heard whether Uncle 
John has recovered, or able to 
return home? We received a 
letter from Robbie about two weeks ago. 
He seems to be well pleased with 
Kansas. I was in Emporia yesterday 
and last night. The college students 
are full of excitement over the 
coming content, on the night 
of February the twelvth when 
the representatives of the differ-
ent colleges of the state again 
meet to contest in 
oratory, at Topeka. V.C.Cook.,

Carroll's roommate, will represent the Emporia College, a copy of whose oration I will send you. The college students are quite confident of him taking first place. Carooll has been elected second delegate and Vern Byars first, from Emporia. There will be about 8 car loads of students from the Emporia College and State Normal go from Emporia. I intend to accompany the college crowd. I am afraid I have dwelt on this to long as I suppose you are not interested in Kan. oritorical contests as much as other affairs. I suppose you have heard that Charlie Jones was in New York Cy. attending a cutting school. He went the first of December and spent about two weeks visiting in Turin. He surprised the Turin folks as they hadn't heard that he was intending to come last. He had a very nice time in Turin and is well pleased with the east.
Papa has been so busy during the last ten days taking inventory and part of the time I have been in the hay press that he has not had time to write. One week ago Monday we commenced to have a regular Kansas blizzard so papa thought that trade would be quiet so that we might commence invoicing but we soon found that it was most too cold to do that.
The weather soon quieted down and then then began to enjoy the other extreme. Sunday was a very warm day. Caroll has not been home since vacation.
I must close, with love from all
Chas. H. Everett
P.S. In regard "to that dollar" that you sent

papa wrote you that we invested it in a new saddle. Please accept many thanks for that and also my pen wiper and the rest of them.
C.H.E.

Dear Aunt Mary, I have just received a letter from Mother telling me of your accident.  I can't tell you how sorry I am.  How you must have suffered before they set it.  Mother said you were very brave and never winced.
